newsitem.title: CANADA: Ontario says not considering sale of Ontario Hydro.
newsitem.headline: Ontario says not considering sale of Ontario Hydro.

text.p: Ontario Hydro, North America's biggest power utility, is no longer a candidate for privatization, the provincial government said on Thursday.

"In terms of what is being considered now and the options we have to deal with Ontario Hydro, privatization is not one of them," Ingrid Thompson, a spokeswoman for Ontario Energy Minister Norm Sterling, said in a phone interview on Thursday.
The dismantling of Ontario Hydro's power monopoly in Canada's most-populous province was a major election promise in 1995 when the ruling Conservatives swept to power.
But Thompson said the government is still intent on bringing competition to Ontario's power market.
"The whole point of the exercise here is not about getting to privatization, it's about getting to competition," Thompson said.

A report last year by a government-appointed committee recommended that the provincially-owned utility lose its 91-year-old monopoly and face competition for Ontario's 3.8 million customers ranging from households to heavy industry.
Ontario Hydro is the continent's largest electricity producer based on installed generating capacity. It operates 69 hydro-electric stations, five nuclear plants and six fossil-fuel stations.

The Toronto Globe and Mail newspaper, citing unnamed sources, said in a report on Thursday that the Ontario government was preparing to split the utility into two publicly-owned companies and open up the electricity market.
Thompson said the government is still reviewing its options and no final decision has been made yet.
